awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Towards a Traffic Analysis Resistant Internet Architecture
awd_abstract_narration:
Many nation states restrict citizen access to information over the Internet by analyzing Internet users' traffic and then blocking traffic deemed controversial or antithetical to the views of the nation state. This project explores an alternative end-to-end network architecture that removes the vulnerability of citizens to traffic analysis. The researchers propose alternative Internet architecture and protocol designs, assesses the impact of such designs on Internet stakeholders, and provide assessment methods for correctness, performance, and scalability of the alternative design. The project broadly impacts multiple domains and research communities, from the network security and anti-censorship communities to those who design and run the Internet. Assuring that individuals around the world can easily access information over the Internet is one of the core, driving principles behind this project.

Traffic analysis uses packet meta-data and side-channels to infer information about communication sessions, encrypted or not, running over a network. Proxy services make traffic analysis difficult by inserting intermediate nodes between packet source and destination, but their success is limited. They can be detected and blocked. The core concept binds communications sessions to dynamic, short-lived, and seemingly random Internet Protocol (IP) addresses. This fundamentally impacts multiple aspects of the Internet: the domain name system (DNS), IP addressing/routing, and packet forwarding. This EAGER project will explore the solution space (scope, capabilities, impact), identify strategies for realization, and develop a prototype to assess key properties of the approach. The project's intellectual merit includes host and network methods based on ephemeral, pseudo-random IP addresses, IPv6 addressing and inter-domain routing, and SDX architecture/functions.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The project explored network solutions that provide network users access to Internet with anonymity, leveraging:

  1. IP addressing and routing methods robust to IP/DNS filtering and traffic analysis-based attacks;
  2. Software defined networking (SDN) based strategies compatible with existing network infrastructure as well as emerging software defined Internet exchange (SDX) capabilities; 
  3. Prototyping and experimentation of the solutions on network testbeds including NSF GENI, PEERING, and the MiniNext/Mininet SDN network emulator.

The project began with a focus on wide area networking over Internet and later examined 5G wireless networks.  The project explored how TCP/IP networking could become more secure by discarding aspects of IP networking (fixed IP addresses, discrete network sessions) that allow traffic analysis. Through four phases of the study, we explored:

  • Phase 1: 
    • Focus: End-to-end address rewrite with OpenFlow SDN application ?TARN? (https://github.com/geddings/TARN).
  • Lessons learned:
    • (Success) SDN rewrite on end user devices, campus gateways, and SDXs has been implemented and verified to work effectively.
    • (Success) Testing on BGP testbed showed global connectivity maintained even as BGP prefixes varied.
    • (Caution) Prefix rewrite is more useful if the prefixes used can change over time to avoid adversaries to learn their association with a specific party. We learned the following issues that limits the practicality of this approach: 
      • Fast BGP route changes raise concerns of instability in global BGP routing stability. Current practice (e.g., https://peering.ee.columbia.edu/aup/) is to not update route for a prefix more frequently that every 10 minutes.
      • BGP update announcements include the AS number the prefix is associated with. To achieve the purpose of not revealing the source and destination organization using the prefix, it?s important that the AS number be owned by a neutral provider that has large numbers of prefixes that can be used by different organizations over time.
      • BGP update repositories exist. This means that network prefix modification may have some utility for avoiding dynamic filtering, but the fact that such changes are public information makes it possible for advanced adversaries to track.
    • (Success) Global BGP testbed experiments across PEERING and GENI.
    • Phase 2: Anonymity Analysis
      • Focus: Assessment of traffic analysis risks over campus network and testbed experiments.
        • NetFlow records on Clemson campus network.
        • Packet size side-channel analysis: VPN vs. SDX-based TARN
  • Lessons learned:
    • CDN and cloud hosting dominate traffic destinations [Barrineau thesis, 2021] ? The majority of destination IP addresses are owned by major cloud and CDN providers (AWS, Google, Microsoft, Fastly). The costs of traffic analysis for adversaries to track and block specific domain names thus increases proportionally to the frequency of IP address shuffling of the cloud services.
    • VPN for end-to-end sessions is vulnerable to packet size side-channel attacks.  Distributed SDX that employs a mesh of SDX facilities to 1) provide packet delivery service between source and destination, 2) deliver split traffic across SDX sites over encrypted sessions, 3) re-assemble the traffic before delivering to the destination, can fully eliminate the packet size side-channel attack [Tusing, 2019].
    • Phase 3:  Broadening TARN?s impacts through international experimentations
      • NSF IRNC: FABRIC Across Borders (FAB, # 2029260), KC Wang, Richard Brooks.
      • European Commission NGI-Atlantic project: ?Responsibility to protect population through peer-to-peer and trusted community (P2PR2P)?, Richard Brooks, https://ngiatlantic.eu/funded-experiments/responsibility-protect-population-through-peer-governance-and-trusted-community. That project supports a United Nations Development Programme project providing legal support to impoverished victims of sexual violence in Chad.
      • Experimental lease for RIPE/32 IPv6 subnet (2001:63f::/32), thanks to the generous support by the German National Research and Education Network.
      • This work informed the team?s work developing networking software to increase the Onion Router?s (Tor?s) stealthiness and goodput. Some of this work is under continuing test and evaluation inside of countries with national firewalls.
      • Phase 4: Expanding into the Wireless Edge
        • Focus: Examination of the 5G wireless network architecture.
          • Mobile access across dense, potentially multi-provider, mmWave cells
          • Experimentation on PAWR testbeds and software simulation.
  • Lessons learned
    • Conducted over-the-air experiments on NSF POWDER testbed.
    • Used and extended OMNeT++ Simu5G software simulation for ultra-low latency and IoT networks.

 

Upon conclusion, the project learned the current state and outlook of anonymous communications over Internet in the following aspects:

  • Encrypted traffic is now dominant on campus networks and Internet.  However, encryption alone does not overcome the risks of traffic analysis attacks (e.g., [Tusing2019])  
  • Due to the prolific BGP intercept attacks, traffic analysis based attacks are real threats.  The primary threat is based on correlation of IP address/domain names, packet sizes, and packet times at source and destination networks.  Disrupting the ability for adversaries to observe this correlation is key to ameliorate the risks.
  • SDX, when implemented as a distributed mesh across multiple locations to split and forward traffic of a transport session (TCP/UDP) in multiple encrypted paths, can substantially reduce the risk of traffic correlation attacks.

 


Last Modified: 12/07/2021
Modified by: Kuang-Ching Wang
por.por_txt_cntn:
The project explored network solutions that provide network users access to Internet with anonymity, leveraging:

IP addressing and routing methods robust to IP/DNS filtering and traffic analysis-based attacks;
Software defined networking (SDN) based strategies compatible with existing network infrastructure as well as emerging software defined Internet exchange (SDX) capabilities; 
Prototyping and experimentation of the solutions on network testbeds including NSF GENI, PEERING, and the MiniNext/Mininet SDN network emulator.


The project began with a focus on wide area networking over Internet and later examined 5G wireless networks.  The project explored how TCP/IP networking could become more secure by discarding aspects of IP networking (fixed IP addresses, discrete network sessions) that allow traffic analysis. Through four phases of the study, we explored:

Phase 1:   

Focus: End-to-end address rewrite with OpenFlow SDN application ?TARN? (https://github.com/geddings/TARN).




Lessons learned:  

(Success) SDN rewrite on end user devices, campus gateways, and SDXs has been implemented and verified to work effectively.
(Success) Testing on BGP testbed showed global connectivity maintained even as BGP prefixes varied.
(Caution) Prefix rewrite is more useful if the prefixes used can change over time to avoid adversaries to learn their association with a specific party. We learned the following issues that limits the practicality of this approach:   

Fast BGP route changes raise concerns of instability in global BGP routing stability. Current practice (e.g., https://peering.ee.columbia.edu/aup/) is to not update route for a prefix more frequently that every 10 minutes.
BGP update announcements include the AS number the prefix is associated with. To achieve the purpose of not revealing the source and destination organization using the prefix, it?s important that the AS number be owned by a neutral provider that has large numbers of prefixes that can be used by different organizations over time.
BGP update repositories exist. This means that network prefix modification may have some utility for avoiding dynamic filtering, but the fact that such changes are public information makes it possible for advanced adversaries to track.


(Success) Global BGP testbed experiments across PEERING and GENI.
Phase 2: Anonymity Analysis  

Focus: Assessment of traffic analysis risks over campus network and testbed experiments.  

NetFlow records on Clemson campus network.
Packet size side-channel analysis: VPN vs. SDX-based TARN






Lessons learned:  

CDN and cloud hosting dominate traffic destinations [Barrineau thesis, 2021] ? The majority of destination IP addresses are owned by major cloud and CDN providers (AWS, Google, Microsoft, Fastly). The costs of traffic analysis for adversaries to track and block specific domain names thus increases proportionally to the frequency of IP address shuffling of the cloud services.
VPN for end-to-end sessions is vulnerable to packet size side-channel attacks.  Distributed SDX that employs a mesh of SDX facilities to 1) provide packet delivery service between source and destination, 2) deliver split traffic across SDX sites over encrypted sessions, 3) re-assemble the traffic before delivering to the destination, can fully eliminate the packet size side-channel attack [Tusing, 2019].
Phase 3:  Broadening TARN?s impacts through international experimentations  

NSF IRNC: FABRIC Across Borders (FAB, # 2029260), KC Wang, Richard Brooks.
European Commission NGI-Atlantic project: ?Responsibility to protect population through peer-to-peer and trusted community (P2PR2P)?, Richard Brooks, https://ngiatlantic.eu/funded-experiments/responsibility-protect-population-through-peer-governance-and-trusted-community. That project supports a United Nations Development Programme project providing legal support to impoverished victims of sexual violence in Chad.
Experimental lease for RIPE/32 IPv6 subnet (2001:63f::/32), thanks to the generous support by the German National Research and Education Network.
This work informed the team?s work developing networking software to increase the Onion Router?s (Tor?s) stealthiness and goodput. Some of this work is under continuing test and evaluation inside of countries with national firewalls.
Phase 4: Expanding into the Wireless Edge  

Focus: Examination of the 5G wireless network architecture.  

Mobile access across dense, potentially multi-provider, mmWave cells
Experimentation on PAWR testbeds and software simulation.








Lessons learned  

Conducted over-the-air experiments on NSF POWDER testbed.
Used and extended OMNeT++ Simu5G software simulation for ultra-low latency and IoT networks.




 

Upon conclusion, the project learned the current state and outlook of anonymous communications over Internet in the following aspects:

Encrypted traffic is now dominant on campus networks and Internet.  However, encryption alone does not overcome the risks of traffic analysis attacks (e.g., [Tusing2019])  
Due to the prolific BGP intercept attacks, traffic analysis based attacks are real threats.  The primary threat is based on correlation of IP address/domain names, packet sizes, and packet times at source and destination networks.  Disrupting the ability for adversaries to observe this correlation is key to ameliorate the risks.
SDX, when implemented as a distributed mesh across multiple locations to split and forward traffic of a transport session (TCP/UDP) in multiple encrypted paths, can substantially reduce the risk of traffic correlation attacks.
